description: Papers about modern peer code review practices, effectiveness, tooling, analytics, and process improvements.
Papers that build or evaluate automated recommenders for software engineering tasks (e.g., reviewer/developer recommendation, change suggestions, naming and typing suggestions).
Studies of SCM history, branching strategies, DVCS migration, merge processes, and their effects on quality and coordination.
Research on OSS communities, governance, onboarding, communication, geographic/organizational distribution, and project migrations.
Work on release processes and tooling, including differential testing, staged rollouts, continuous delivery, and RE 3.0 directions.
Applications of machine learning/LLMs to SE tasks such as merge resolution, type inference, reviewer recommendation, API suggestion, and code convention inference.
Papers examining developer use of generative AI (e.g., Copilot), impacts on workflows and productivity, and trust/responsibility concerns.
Research on static/dynamic analysis techniques, idiom mining, heap structure, typing for dynamic languages, and automated review decomposition.
Studies of what drives developers' productivity and satisfaction, including workday factors, remote work, and measurement.
Findings on management and team practices: manager attributes, coordination, build teams, agile adoption, and OKR use.
Analyses of communication and collaboration networks (mailing lists, reviews), community structure, and links to code activity.
Empirical work on factors and models predicting defects and failures, including socio-technical metrics, ownership, clones, branching, and environmental effects.
Research on DevOps artifacts and practices (e.g., Dockerfiles), best-practice mining/enforcement, and correlated code/config changes.
Studies of how developers adopt, trust, and integrate tools (static analyzers, homegrown tools, DVCS, AI-enabled tools) into workflows.
Research that collects qualitative data through semi-structured or structured interviews with practitioners.
Studies that gather quantitative or mixed-method data via questionnaires from developers or teams.
Analyses that mine version-control histories, issue trackers, or review systems to derive empirical insights.
Methods that construct and analyze networks from communication, review, or collaboration data to study structure and dynamics.
In-depth investigations of one or a small number of projects/organizations to understand practices, effects, or phenomena.
In-vivo evaluations or production deployments of tools/services in real development environments.
Use of statistical modeling and inference (e.g., regression, hazard models, hypothesis testing, effect sizes) to analyze empirical data.
Studies that instrument and analyze large-scale runtime, usage, or operational logs/telemetry from software and development tools.
Papers that create or curate datasets, platforms, or research tools to enable empirical SE studies and reproducibility.
